title.narrative: Save the Children Sweden - REJ Programme
Save the Children Sweden - REJ Programme

description.narrative: The Save the Children programme on "Giving Rights to the Silent Majority Children has been funded by the Embassy of Sweden since 2008 Annual reports and various field visits done by the Embassy staff have shown that there is a clear direction towards achieveing the objectives set at both outcome and impact level. There are significant and very relevant qualitative results at both the national, district and district level. It is clear that the Government and other key stakeholders are recognising the benefits of the multisectoral approach in addressing child rights governance matters. Furthermore, the project has demonstrated that the Government is consistently and gradually taking over coordination and ownership of the child rights governance mechanisms. The programme is suggested to be extended for the period January - June 2015 in order to provide an opportunity for a development of a comprehensive child rights governanace and child protection programme and systematic phaseout of the current support. During this period the key focus will be on strengthening the enabling environment for sustainability of the programme interventions through more focused advocacy activities, strengthening accountability and child safeguarding and children's councils, documentation of results and more indepth work with media partners to promote increased knowledge about child rights and legal provisions for general public, victims and potential victims.

The objective of the project is to empower and build the capacity of most vulnerable children in 7 districts in Tanzania so that they can claim their rights to protection, health care & obtain appropriate support from quality social, political, economic & legal systems from community to national level.the primary focus is to support children and key duty bearers to identify and adress child rights violation.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The intended outcome of the Project was to bring forth recognition and reinforcement of Childrens rights and governance, so that child participation is understood and implemented and that children are heard and their issues are given priority in all aspects of planning for development. In the process of striving to acheive the desired results, Save the Children worked closely with Ministries, departments and agencies, civil society, international partners and Childrens Councils in seven districts across the country.The key achievements related to the intended outcome include: 1) The Child rights agenda in Tanzania has been considerably strengthened, and decision makers at national and district level regard Save the Children as a core adviser on Child rights matters. 2) Children's Council capacity in seven districts has been strengthened and mmebers participate in decision making forums at the district, regional, national and international levels. 3) The Proposed Constitution of Tanzania has for the first time included children's recommendations. The fact that children from Children Councils actively participated and contributed in the process has allowed for other key issues to be considered a priority, such as the right to education, the right to survival beyond five years and review of the current Marriage Act that allows marriage below the age of 18. 4) Regional Child Rights networks have been engaged with regional and district government to integrate and monitor Child rights issues through district plans and budgets. 5) Political parties representatives have incorporated Child rights in their manifestos. 6) Establishment of the first Regional Childrens Council, uniting 6 districts in Lindi Region. The Childrens Council is hosted within the Regional Commissioners Office. 7) The Universal Periodic Review ( UPR) alternative report submmitted to the Human Rights Council with contributiosn from 70 CC members and 80 CSO representatives included 5 recommendations on education, 6 of Child Protection/ Violence against Children and 6 on Health. 8) Increased media coverage on children issues. Between September - December 2015, a total of 880 news items were reported.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
